dischargeDispositionCode.displayName: Discharged/transferred to a short-term general hospital for inpatient care

section.title: Hospital Course
section.text:
The patient was admitted to the Observation unit, and continued on oxygen and antibiotics.
Overnight, the patient apparently began to complain of increasing chest pain and appeared to the nurse to have mounting exhaustion and respiratory distress and a pulse ox of 91 n 2 Liters/min of 02.
His temperature spiked to 103.8 degrees and his BP decreased to 100/60. His blood cultures came back positive for staphylococcus, characterized as community acquired MRSA. He was seen by the critical care specialist through teleconsult and diagnosed with sepsis. He was empirically placed on Vancomycin, pending further culture results.
Although O2 had been placed, elevating his oxygen saturations to the mid to 90s, he continued to complain of symptoms, as noted above, and became progressively more confused.
Chest x-ray demonstrated an increase in the right lower lobe infiltrate, and signs of early congestive heart failure.
Because of concern regarding MRSA pneumonia, sepsis, and developing CHF, the hospitalist service was contacted for transfer to the Tertiary Medical Center, which was approved.
Per their request, the patient received one gram of Rocephin intravenously and a nasogastric and Foley were placed, and an arterial blood gas was drawn by respiratory therapy.

text.paragraph: Pneumonia
This patient has an acute pneumonia.

At this point, I am unable to rule out myocardial infarction.
Cannot rule out MI in spite of a relatively normal EKG.

tr.td: Intravenous Rocephin at one gram dosage
Nasal oxygen at 2 liters per minute
Transfer to tertiary hospital by ambulance

text.paragraph: Shortness of breath, fever, and chest pain.
Hypertension, mild type 2 diabetes, and mild COPD.
The patient first developed a low grade fever 4 days ago, followed by increasing fatigue, cough and aching in his chest.
He was seen initially in the ER 2 days ago and started on Proventil (Albuterol Sulfate).
Today his fever increased to 102 degrees and he became increasingly confused.
His family believes he has mild COPD due to his smoking, but has never been hospitalized for respiratory problems before.
Today, the patient presents himself in severe respiratory distress, with fatigue and significant confusion.
He has developed mild hypertension with a BP of 160/100, but no signs of stroke or motor impairment.
More complete history cannot be taken because of the patientâ€™s confusion.
VITAL SIGNS: Temperature 103.8 degrees. Pulse 128. Respirations 48. Blood pressure 156/100. Initial oxygen saturations on room air are 94.
GENERAL: Reveals a very anxious, exhausted-appearing male with labored breathing.
HEENT: Head is normocephalic and atraumatic.
NECK: The neck is supple with significant JVD jugular venous distention.
LUNGS: Auscultation of the chest reveals very distant and faint breath sounds, bilaterally, with coarse rales throughout the right lung. Percussion suggests a significant effusion on the right.
HEART: Cardiac examination reveals sinus tachycardia, without pronounced murmur.
ABDOMEN: Soft to palpation, no organomegaly. Extremities: With 1+ edema.

tr.td: sinus tachycardia and 2-3 PVCs per minute, but no evidence of acute ischemia.
suboptimal in quality, with an infiltrates in the right middle and lower lobe, a right pleural effusion, and no pneumothorax.
yellow clear urine. Specific gravity greater than 1.030 with 2+ ketones, 1+ blood and 3+ protein. No white cells and 0-2 red cells.

act.text: Possible flu-like symptoms for three days.

text.paragraph: Active Concerns
Limited, secondary to the patientâ€™s condition.
HEENT: without headache, visual disturbance, mild hearing loss
Respiratory: Mild COPD with long smoking history, Hx of pneumonia several years ago
Cardiac: negative, Risk factors include abnormal lipids, smoking
GI: negative
Genitourinary: Hx of benign GI polyps
